Learner Referral for Cost-Effective Federated Learning Over Hierarchical IoT Networks

Yulan Gao, Ziqiang Ye, Yue Xiao, and Wei Xiang Y. Gao, Z. Ye, and Y. Xiao are with the National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Communications, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC), Chengdu 611731, China (e-mail: yulangaomath@163.com; yysxiaoyu@hotmail.com; xiaoyue@uestc.edu.cn).W. Xiang is with the School of Engineering and Mathematical Sciences, La Trobe University, Victoria 3086, Australia (e-mail: W.Xiang@latrobe.edu.au).
Abstract

The paradigm of federated learning (FL) to address data privacy concerns by locally training parameters on resource-constrained clients in a distributed manner has garnered significant attention. Nonetheless, FL is not applicable when not all clients within the coverage of the FL server are registered with the FL network. To bridge this gap, this paper proposes joint learner referral aided federated client selection (LRef-FedCS), along with communications and computing resource scheduling, and local model accuracy optimization (LMAO) methods. These methods are designed to minimize the cost incurred by the worst-case participant and ensure the long-term fairness of FL in hierarchical Internet of Things (HieIoT) networks. Utilizing the Lyapunov optimization technique, we reformulate the original problem into a stepwise joint optimization problem (JOP). Subsequently, to tackle the mixed-integer non-convex JOP, we separatively and iteratively address LRef-FedCS and LMAO through the centralized method and self-adaptive global best harmony search (SGHS) algorithm, respectively. To enhance scalability, we further propose a distributed LRef-FedCS approach based on a matching game to replace the centralized method described above. Numerical simulations and experimental results on the MNIST/CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that our proposed LRef-FedCS approach could achieve a good balance between pursuing high global accuracy and reducing cost.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, learner referral, client selection, matching game.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a transformative computational stategy, conceived within the vast landscape of artificial intelligence (AI), to accomodate the intensifying need for data privacy. This inventive framework is predicated on the essential concept of computation decentralization, thereby shifting the computational workload from the central server onto a network of local devices (a.k.a. clients and workers) [1]. By doing so, privacy preservation is ensured for data owners, as FL avoids transmit transporting end devices’ raw data to the central server. From an application standpoint, given the inevitable proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices (e.g., mobile phone, iPad, laptop, vehicles, etc.), we are witnessing a measured yet steady ascent of collaborative training parameters [2, 3]. For instance, UberEATs (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uber_Eats), launched by Uber in 2014, has adopted the FL paradigm to improve on-time delivery while simultaneously protecting data privacy of both customers and delivery partners [4].

For FL in wireless IoT networks, unreliable date is likely to be uploaded intentionally or unintentionally by mobile clients [5, 6], resulting in a low learning quality. So, how to design trustworthy and reliable federated client selection (FedCS) strategies is a challenge in wireless FL systems. In addition, the model quality relies on frequent communications between the FL server and clients, which leads to another challenge in communications and computation. Accordingly, reaping the potential benefits of wireless FL in practice requires meeting the aforementioned challenges in FedCS and diverse resource management. Among the early iconic contributions in this area, the authors of [7, 8] proposed a probabilistic FedCS approach to minimize the training loss while guaranteeing model fast convergence. The authors of [9] used the Lagrangian dual framework to investigate the weighted sum of energy consumption and time cost (WSET)-based minimization problem from the perspective of joint transmit power and computation resources allocation as well as local model accuracy optimization (LMAO). The aforementioned studies for FL in wireless IoT networks assume that all participating clients are willing to learn collaboratively and continuously. In fact, there are various reasons such that mobile clients are reluctant to contribute any learning resources to participate in the training process, e.g., limited CPU capability, battery, and their own requirements/schedule. Therefore, incentive mechanisms which incentivize the trustworthy and cost-effective learning behavior become a catalyst for making wireless FL a reality.

Nowadays, social attributes have become a vital factor for realizing trustworthy multi-resource sharing thanks to the success of Social Internet of Things (SIoT) [10], where social relationships can be built among mobile users via online social networks (e.g., Twitter, Facebook, and WeChat, etc.). The knowledge of mutual social relationships among IoT devices can be beneficial to trustworthy and reliable FedCS, thereby mitigating malicious attacks throughout the learning process. Discussions on exploiting SIoT features in the FL paradigm have gradually attracted the attention of researchers in recent years. Most research efforts to date have focused on clustering the FL framework by leveraging the social relationships among IoT devices for minimizing the loss function [11, 12, 13]. More recently, the authors of [14] used social relationships among mobile clients to design trustworthy and efficient wireless federated edge learning. These investigations, however, are based on the premise that all clients (i.e., any client covered by the FL server) are known to the FL server. In this framework, the fundamental assumption is that all clients could fully and spontaneously participate in the complete training process, without taking into account the time-varying states and schedules of clients in practice. Motivated by this, we develop socially-driven trustworthy and cost-effective leaner referral mechanism aided (LRef)-FedCS policies for FL in hierarchical (Hie)IoT networks. To accentuate the role of social trust, we introduce a novel hierarchical dimension within the HieIoT network, founded on the establishment of a social relationship between the client and the FL server. Consequently, we categorize all clients under the coverage of the FL server into two distinct types, namely Registered FL clients (RC) and Unregistered FL clients (UnRC), based on this relationship’s presence or absence.

The main goal of this paper is to design efficient joint LRef-FedCS and LMAO schemes for the time-average WSET minimization and fairness guarantees in the HeiIoT FL network, where RCs will recommend trustworthy UnRCs as temporary learners in some training rounds. Specifically, the long-term fairness metric adopted in this work is defined from the perspective of the RCs, which can effectively incentivize RCs to perform the learner referral process. Drawing on the Lyapunov optimization technique, we transform the complex time-coupled WSET minimization problem into a step-by-step online joint optimization problem (JOP). Notably, a practical and challenging scenario is considered, where all RCs and UnRCs can move around within the area covered by the server and cannot continuously participate in the complete training process. The novelty and contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We define two participation modes of RCs according to their current status, dubbed the direct participation mode (DParM) and the learner referral mode (LRefM), respectively. We further classify the LRefM into the Partial- and the Full-LRefM based on the current requirements of the recommended UnRCs. The main thrust of introducing the above definitions is devoted to facilitating the LRef-FedCS and realizing on-demand and rational scheduling of clients’ surplus resources.

  • •

    To solve the step-by-step online JOP, we propose two algorithms by employing the centralized search, matching game, and self-adaptive global best harmony search (SGHS) algorithm. We analyse the stability and convergence of the matching game based LRef-FedCS approach. The complexity of the matching game based LRef-FedCS approach is upper bounded by M​N𝑀𝑁MN, where M𝑀M and N𝑁N are the number of RCs and UnRCs, respectively.

  • •

    We run extensive simulations to assess performance of the LRef-FedCS methods for FL in the HieIoT network. Results show that the solution tightness behavior is sensitive to the balance parameter of Lyapunov, and the distributed method can perform closely to the optimal solution with only 2.33%percent2.332.33\% bias within 101010 iterations. Moreover, the results of experiments on the MNIST/CIFAR-10 datasets show that the proposed LRef-FedCS scheme strikes a good balance between pursuing high-quality of FL training and reducing system cost.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The related work is presented in Sec. II. The preliminary of FL and system model are given in Sec. III and Sec. IV, respectively. The problem formulation and the online algorithm design are respectively presented in Sec. V and Sec. VI. Sec. VII introduces an distributed LRef-FedCS method based on matching game theory, and Sec. VIII reports the results of simulations and experiments. Finally, conclusions are presented in Sec. IX.

II Related Work

The framework of reliable client selection and scheduling round-by-round focuses mainly on the long-term benefits, and it has emerged as a prominent area of focus in the domain of FL research within wireless IoT networks. An established theoretical tool for problems of this kind is provided by Lyapunov concept-based optimization theory [15, 16]. Along this line, most works jointly select energy-efficient clients and schedule resources in different training rounds to achieve fairness or maximize utility [17, 18, 19]. Specifically, the authors of [17] proposed an algorithm that only utilizes currently available wireless channel information for joint client selection and bandwidth allocation to meet a preset long-term performance requirement. They further studied the fairness-guaranteed client selection issue for FL in edge networks [18]. In [19], the training time minimization problem for the adaptive client selection design in asynchronous FL was investigated, where the client availability and long-term fairness were considered. It worth mentioning that the Lyapunov concept-based algorithm is particularly cognizant of time/slot coupled constraints and objectives, i.e., long-term utilities and constraints. Also incentive mechanisms have become indispensible for FL to sustain long-term joint client/learner selection and resource scheduling. The authors of [20] formulated a procurement auction to model and analyze the competitive cost minimization problem via selecting and scheduling clients in different training rounds. For critical energy infrastructure systems, the work in [21] developed a multidimensional contract framework to incentivize clients to participate in asynchronous FL for learning accuracy maximization. More recently, the authors of [22] used repeated games in the infinite time horizon to model and analyze clients’ interactions in the long-term cross-silo FL process. Their proposed framework is able to reduce the number of free riders and increase the amount of local data for model training.

The integration of social network features with FL has the potential to promote trustworthy and reliable FedCS in FL networks. A few early studies presented relevant solutions. In [23], a clustering algorithm based on social awareness-aided cluster head selection was provided to address the global training time minimization problem. The proposed framework enables reliable self-organizing FL, where both social relationships and computational resources of the devices are take into account in selecting the cluster head. A framework of discentralized FL on single-sided trust social networks was proposed in [24]. Their simulation results and mathematical analysis on rigorous regret show the benefit of communicating with trusted users in the FL network. Furthermore, a social effect based incentive mechanism for federated edge learning was designed to defend against malicious or inactive learners [14]. In addition, this social federated edge learning framework establishes a trust model via indirect social incentives. Different from the above studies, we propose joint LRef-FedCS and diverse resource scheduling schemes in a more realistic scenario, where not all clients are registered at the FL platform (i.e., not all clients are known to the FL server). Moreover, we also leverage the social relationships among all clients (RCs and UnRCs) to facilitate the trustworthy LRef-FedCS process in a practical scenario, where all RCs and UnRCs can freely move around within the area covered by the server.

III Preliminary of Federated Learning

The learning process of FL minimizes the loss function through frequent communication between FL server and learners to update model and gradient until the model converges [9]. Each learner iteratively computes the local model and the gradient until a local accuracy 0≤θ≤10𝜃10\leq\theta\leq 1 is achieved and upload them to the FL server. Then, all collected local parameters and gradients are aggregated to generate a global model 𝝎𝝎\boldsymbol{\omega}. When a specific global accuracy 0≤ϵ≤10italic-ϵ10\leq\epsilon\leq 1 is reached, the entire training process is terminated. Upon achieving an global accuracy level ϵ,italic-ϵ\epsilon, a number of training iterations are required, causing interaction between learners and FL server. As mentioned in [9, 25], the upper bound of training rounds is closely related to the local accuracy θ𝜃\theta and the global model accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, which is specifically expressed as Tg​(ϵ,θ)=𝒪​(log⁡(1/ϵ))/(1−θ).subscript𝑇𝑔italic-ϵ𝜃𝒪1italic-ϵ1𝜃T_{g}(\epsilon,\theta)={\cal O}(\log(1/\epsilon))/(1-\theta). For a fixed global accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, so the upper bound of training rounds can be normalized to Tg=1/(1−θ).subscript𝑇𝑔11𝜃T_{g}=1/(1-\theta). Likewise, the upper bound of local iterations is normalized to log⁡(1/θ)1𝜃\log(1/\theta)111Here, θ𝜃\theta and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon are the gradient difference between two successive iterations of loss function on local and global models, respectively..

IV System Model

We consider an FL system in a HieIoT network consisting of a set ℳ≜{v1,…,vM}≜ℳsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑀{\cal M}\triangleq\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{M}\} of M𝑀M RCs (i.e., clients registered at the FL platform) and a set of 𝒩≜{v1,…,vN}≜𝒩subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑁{\cal N}\triangleq\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{N}\} of N𝑁N UnRCs. The set of all RCs and UnRCs is denoted by 𝒱≜{v1,v2,…,v|𝒱|}≜𝒱subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2…subscript𝑣𝒱{\cal V}\triangleq\{v_{1},v_{2},\ldots,v_{|{\cal V}|}\} and |𝒱|=M+N.𝒱𝑀𝑁|{\cal V}|=M+N. The FL server first broadcast the information of a FL job to all RCs, but it does not have access to the information of UnRCs. Moreover, the trust among clients can be established through SIoTs such as WeChat, Twitter, and Facebook, etc., so the trust remains unchanged for a long time. In addition, without loss of generality, we assume that for each UnRC vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N}, there exists at least one RC (vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M}) having a social relationship with the UnRC. This assumption is reasonable because if there is no trust value from any RC to UnRC vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N}, then vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} will not be recommended by RCs (i.e., it will not participate in any task). In this context, we first remove this type of UnRCs when implementing LRef-FedCS. Denote by 𝑾=[wm,n]∈ℝM×N𝑾delimited-[]subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛superscriptℝ𝑀𝑁{\boldsymbol{W}}=[w_{m,n}]\in{\mathbb{R}}^{M\times N} the trust matrix with entries wm,n∈[0,1]subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛01w_{m,n}\in[0,1] representing the trust value between RC vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} and UnRC vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n}, where wm,n=0subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛0w_{m,n}=0 means vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} and vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} are strangers and wm,n∈(0,1]subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛01w_{m,n}\in(0,1] otherwise. V Problem Formulation

V-A Participation Mode Decision Model

Before introducing the LRef-FedCS model, we first define the participation mode decision model (PMDM) shown in Fig. 1. In the PMDM, each RC acts according to its current personal schedule (sufficient or insufficient computing resources), where an action here represents an RC’s decision to directly execute a training task or recommend a trustworthy UnRC as a candidate, these two actions are termed DParM and LRefM, respectively. We assume that each RC acts rationally, with actions predicated on its current state and the trust value with the candidate UnRCs. A binary variable ϕm​[t]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚delimited-[]𝑡\phi_{m}[t] is defined to represent the two participation modes for RC vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} in time slot t𝑡t (i.e., corresponding to the t​-th𝑡-tht\text{-th} training task announced by the FL server), shown as follows:

ϕm​[t]={0, if ​vm​ uses DParM on the training task ​t,1, if ​vm​ uses LRefM on the training task ​t.subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚delimited-[]𝑡cases0 if subscript𝑣𝑚 uses DParM on the training task 𝑡1 if subscript𝑣𝑚 uses LRefM on the training task 𝑡\phi_{m}[t]=\begin{cases}0,&\text{~{}if~{}}v_{m}\text{~{}uses DParM on the training task~{}}t,\\ 1,&\text{~{}if~{}}v_{m}\text{~{}uses LRefM on the training task~{}}t.\end{cases} (1)

The introduction of PMDM is conducive to describe the LRef-FedCS process. We further classify the LRefM into two modes based on the current requirements of the recommended UnRC: 1) Partial-LRefM: the mode is for recommending UnRCs with their own quality of service (QoS) requirements. That is, the recommended UnRCs need to reserve certain resources to guarantee their personal QoS requirements in some training rounds; 2) Full-LRefM: the mode is proposed for the scenario where the recommended UnRCs are inactive, i.e., they do not have specific QoS requirements in some training rounds.

V-B Communication Phase

It is evident that the LRef-FedCS strategy is inextricably linked to the RCs’ participation mode decision-making process. In order to facilitate the learner referral process of RCs, we denote an auxiliary notation in the view of each RC vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} by 𝒩m≜𝒩∪{vm}.≜subscript𝒩𝑚𝒩subscript𝑣𝑚{\cal N}_{m}\triangleq{\cal N}\cup\{v_{m}\}. Next, we derive the achieved data rate for LRefM, according to the states of the recommended UnRCs. V-C Local Computation Phase

For each client vi∈𝒩msubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}, the budget of the CPU cycle frequency (cycle/byte) is represented by fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}. Similarly, upon introducing the resource scheduler Π​(⋅)Π⋅\Pi(\cdot) on UnRC side, the computation time at vi∈𝒩msubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m} for one local iteration can be expressed as

Tm,icmp​[t]=Qi​[t]​bi{ϕm​[t]​αm,i​[t]+(1−ϕm​[t])​αm,i​Π​(wm,i)}​fi,superscriptsubscriptT𝑚𝑖cmpdelimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑄𝑖delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑏𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡1subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖Πsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖\displaystyle\text{T}_{m,i}^{\text{cmp}}[t]=\frac{Q_{i}[t]b_{i}}{\left\{\phi_{m}[t]\alpha_{m,i}[t]+(1-\phi_{m}[t])\alpha_{m,i}\Pi(w_{m,i})\right\}f_{i}}, (9)

where Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} represent the numbers of training samples and CPU cycles that are required to process a data sample, respectively.

Additionally, in the HieIoT network FL system, we assume that two UnRCs can be randomly matched to form a C2C link within a distance of d𝑑d, each serving as a transceiver for the other. In time slot t𝑡t, if UnRC vi∈𝒩act,mtru​[t]∩𝒩msubscript𝑣𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒩act𝑚trudelimited-[]𝑡subscript𝒩𝑚v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{\text{act},m}^{\text{tru}}[t]\cap{\cal N}_{m} is recommended as a learner, the instantaneous data rate of the C2C pair link (vi,vj)subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗(v_{i},v_{j}) can be expressed as

In principle, each UnRC can randomly match any other UnRC within its selection range.

V-D Problem Formulation

Decision variables. As formulated in Section V.A, the participation mode decision-making and LRef-FedCS process as they align with the timeline of announced training tasks (or time slots), can be regarded as a renewal system, which is shown in Fig. 2. The set of durations for successive training tasks is {T​[1],T​[2],…}Tdelimited-[]1Tdelimited-[]2…\{\text{T}[1],\text{T}[2],\ldots\}. Define τ​[1]=0𝜏delimited-[]10\tau[1]=0, and for each training task t𝑡t define τ​[t]𝜏delimited-[]𝑡\tau[t] as the t​th𝑡tht\text{th} renewal time instance, i.e., τ[t]:≜∑l=1tT[l].\tau[t]:\triangleq\sum\nolimits_{l=1}^{t}\text{T}[l]. Note that the defined renewal time instance is the time point at which the FL server announces the task. As indicated before, the status333Status of RCs is determined according to whether its computation resources are surplus. and classification of clients are critical for performing the PMDM and LRef-FedCS. As mentioned in Section V.A, we give a more precise definition of binary variable αm,i​[t]subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡\alpha_{m,i}[t] on the extended set 𝒩msubscript𝒩𝑚{\cal N}_{m} of each RC vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M}, where αm,m​[t]=1subscript𝛼𝑚𝑚delimited-[]𝑡1\alpha_{m,m}[t]=1 iff ϕm​[t]=1.subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚delimited-[]𝑡1\phi_{m}[t]=1. Moreover, it is assumed that each RC can only recommend at most one UnRC and each UnRC can only be associated with one RC in any time slot, i.e., ∑i∈𝒩mαm,i​[t]≤1,∀vm∈ℳformulae-sequencesubscript𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡1for-allsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳ\sum_{i\in{\cal N}_{m}}\alpha_{m,i}[t]\leq 1,\forall v_{m}\in{\cal M} and ∑m=1Mαm,i​[t]≤1,∀vi∈𝒩m.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡1for-allsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚\sum_{m=1}^{M}\alpha_{m,i}[t]\leq 1,\forall v_{i}\in{{\cal N}_{m}}. Let 𝑨​[t]={𝒂​[t]}𝑨delimited-[]𝑡𝒂delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{A}}[t]=\{\boldsymbol{a}[t]\} be the set of RCs’ actions at the renewal time instance τ​[t]𝜏delimited-[]𝑡\tau[t] with entries 𝒂​[t]𝒂delimited-[]𝑡\boldsymbol{a}[t] composed of PMDM ϕ​[t]bold-italic-ϕdelimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{\phi}[t]} and LRef-FedCS 𝜶​[t]𝜶delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}[t], respectively. That is, 𝒂​[t]≜{ϕ​[t],𝜶​[t]},≜𝒂delimited-[]𝑡bold-italic-ϕdelimited-[]𝑡𝜶delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{a}}[t]\triangleq\{{\boldsymbol{\phi}}[t],{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}[t]\}, where ϕ​[t]={ϕm​[t]∈{0,1},∀vm∈ℳ}bold-italic-ϕdelimited-[]𝑡formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚delimited-[]𝑡01for-allsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳ{\boldsymbol{\phi}}[t]=\{\phi_{m}[t]\in\{0,1\},\forall v_{m}\in{\cal M}\} and 𝜶​[t]={αm,i​[t]∈{0,1},vi∈𝒩m,∀vm∈ℳ}.𝜶delimited-[]𝑡formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡01formulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚for-allsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳ{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}[t]=\{\alpha_{m,i}[t]\in\{0,1\},v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m},\forall v_{m}\in{\cal M}\}. Therefore, at each renewal time instance, the FL server makes a decision on 𝒂​[t].𝒂delimited-[]𝑡\boldsymbol{a}[t].

Constraints and assumptions. (1) Long-term fairness requirement of FL training: The cost-effective action decision-making may not be the best strategy in terms of the learning quality, and the requirement of FL training in action decision-making is another factor that needs to be taken into account. Moreover, the FL server can only broadcast the training task to RCs. In this context, how to eliminate the “Tragedy of the Commons” [28] to sustain a long-term learning quality is another factor that should be considered. Accordingly, we introduce a time-average constraint (14), which ensures that the expected proportion of recommended learners for each RC vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} does not lower than Δ.Δ\Delta.444Typically, the value of ΔΔ\Delta is less than or equal to MM+N𝑀𝑀𝑁\frac{M}{M+N}. In this paper, we set Δ=MM+NΔ𝑀𝑀𝑁\Delta=\frac{M}{M+N}

lim¯R→∞⁡1R​∑t=1R𝔼​{∑vi∈𝒩mαm,i​[t]}≥Δ,∀vm∈ℳ.formulae-sequencesubscriptlimit-supremum→𝑅1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑅𝔼subscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡Δfor-allsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳ\displaystyle\varlimsup_{R\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{R}\sum\nolimits_{t=1}^{R}{\mathbb{E}}\left\{\sum\nolimits_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}}\alpha_{m,i}[t]\right\}\geq\Delta,\forall v_{m}\in{\cal M}. (14)

(2) Duration of local iteration: To alleviate the straggler issue, for each potential client vi∈𝒩m,vm∈ℳformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m},v_{m}\in{\cal M}, the computing time of one local iteration is upper bounded by TmaxcmpsuperscriptsubscriptTcmp\text{T}_{\max}^{\text{cmp}}, i.e.,

≤Tmaxcmp,∀vi∈𝒩m,vm∈ℳ.formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscriptTcmpformulae-sequencefor-allsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝑣𝑚ℳ\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\leq\text{T}_{\max}^{\text{cmp}},\forall v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m},v_{m}\in{\cal M}. (15)

(3) Long-term QoS requirement of UnRCs: As stated in Section V.A, trust-aided resource scheduling can incentivize UnRCs to temporarily replace some trustworthy RCs to participate in the training process. To model such QoS requirements, it is assumed that UnRCs’ best interest is to pursue long-term requirements, which can be described as

lim¯R→∞⁡∑t=1R∑m=1Mαm,n​[t]​ℐ𝒩act,mtru​[t]​(n)​𝔼​{Rnc2c​[t]}∑t=1R∑m=1Mαm,n​[t]​ℐ𝒩act,mtru​[t]​(n)≥Rn,minc2c,subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝛼𝑚𝑛delimited-[]𝑡subscriptℐsuperscriptsubscript𝒩act𝑚trudelimited-[]𝑡𝑛𝔼superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑛c2cdelimited-[]𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝛼𝑚𝑛delimited-[]𝑡subscriptℐsuperscriptsubscript𝒩act𝑚trudelimited-[]𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑛c2c\displaystyle\varlimsup\limits_{R\rightarrow\infty}\frac{\sum_{t=1}^{R}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\alpha_{m,n}[t]{\cal I}_{{\cal N}_{\text{act},m}^{\text{tru}}[t]}(n){\mathbb{E}}\left\{R_{n}^{\text{c2c}}[t]\right\}}{\sum_{t=1}^{R}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\alpha_{m,n}[t]{\cal I}_{{\cal N}_{\text{act},m}^{\text{tru}}[t]}(n)}\geq R_{n,\min}^{\text{c2c}},

Through defining ℐ𝒩act,mtru​[t]​(n)subscriptℐsuperscriptsubscript𝒩act𝑚trudelimited-[]𝑡𝑛{\cal I}_{{\cal N}_{\text{act},m}^{\text{tru}}[t]}(n), the denominator of (16) can be used to calculate participation rounds of vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N} with the C2C links.

We employ the weighted sum method to address the trade-off among multiple objectives using parameters λtsuperscript𝜆t\lambda^{\text{t}} and λesuperscript𝜆e\lambda^{\text{e}} with 0≤λt,λe≤1,λt+λe=1formulae-sequence0superscript𝜆tformulae-sequencesuperscript𝜆e1superscript𝜆tsuperscript𝜆e10\leq\lambda^{\text{t}},\lambda^{\text{e}}\leq 1,\lambda^{\text{t}}+\lambda^{\text{e}}=1. 𝒢m,i​[t]=11−θ​[t]​(λt​Tm,i​[t]+λe​Em,i​[t]).subscript𝒢𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡11𝜃delimited-[]𝑡superscript𝜆tsubscriptT𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡superscript𝜆esubscriptE𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡\displaystyle{\cal G}_{m,i}[t]=\frac{1}{1-\theta[t]}\left(\lambda^{\text{t}}\text{T}_{m,i}[t]+\lambda^{\text{e}}\text{E}_{m,i}[t]\right). It is worth noting that our model is sufficiently broad, since weights can be adjusted to emphasize a sub-objective over another, potentially honing the focus on minimizing solely energy consumption or time cost. Given the above discussions, we introduce the following action policy making problem

αm,i​[t]∈{0,1},∀vi∈𝒩m,vm∈ℳ,formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡01formulae-sequencefor-allsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝑣𝑚ℳ\displaystyle\hskip 15.00002pt\alpha_{m,i}[t]\in\{0,1\},\forall v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m},v_{m}\in{\cal M}, (19d)
∑m=1Mαm,i​[t]≤1,∀vi∈𝒩m,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡1for-allsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚\displaystyle\hskip 15.00002pt\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{M}\alpha_{m,i}[t]\leq 1,\forall v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}, (19e)
∑vi∈𝒩mαm,i​[t]≤1,∀vm∈ℳ,formulae-sequencesubscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡1for-allsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳ\displaystyle\hskip 15.00002pt\sum\nolimits_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}}\alpha_{m,i}[t]\leq 1,\forall v_{m}\in{\cal M}, (19f)

where 𝒂​[t]𝒂delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{a}}[t] captures the actions of participation mode decision and LRef-FedCS at renewal time instance τ​[t]𝜏delimited-[]𝑡\tau[t], which is our optimization target. Intuitively, our goal is to minimize the long-term WSET of the worst-case participant subject to the long-term requirements of FL training (14) and UnRCs (16), which tolerate short-term violation, along with the non-negotiable additional hard constraint, as denoted in (15) It is noted taht, (16) is an additional constraint indicating that UnRCs will act as temporary participants for some trustworthy RCs only when the long-term QoS exceeds a certain level.

Challenges: One would note that problem (19) is a time-coupling scheduling problem without constraints (15) and (19b)-(19f), regarding the long-term objective and requirements of FL training (14) and UnRCs (16). Our primary challenges are mainly derived from the time-coupling constraints (14) and (16), which are quite difficult for an offline solution to deal with. In addition, suppose that the participation mode decision and the LRef-FedCS process are made before the real training process. Therefore, for an alternative sub-optimal solution, in the following section, we will elaborate on our transformation of the offline problem to an online scheduling problem via Lyapunov-concept optimization so as to satisfy the time-coupling requirements of FL training and UnRCs.

VI Online Algorithm Design

VI-A Problem Transformation under Lyapunov Framework

In this subsection, we first utilize the Lyapunov optimization framework to transform (19) into an online problem. First, we introduce a virtual queue γm​[t]subscript𝛾𝑚delimited-[]𝑡\gamma_{m}[t] for vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} to deal with the long-term fairness constraint (14). Likewise, we denote by zn​[t]subscript𝑧𝑛delimited-[]𝑡z_{n}[t] the virtual queue for vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N}, to deal with the long-term QoS requirements (16). Specially, γmsubscript𝛾𝑚\gamma_{m} and znsubscript𝑧𝑛z_{n} evolve in the FL process through complying with the following rules:

γm​[t+1]=subscript𝛾𝑚delimited-[]𝑡1absent\displaystyle\gamma_{m}[t+1]= [γm​[t]+Δ−∑vi∈𝒩mαm,i​[t]]+,∀vm∈ℳ,superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝛾𝑚delimited-[]𝑡Δsubscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡for-allsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳ\displaystyle\left[\gamma_{m}[t]+\Delta-\sum\nolimits_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}}\alpha_{m,i}[t]\right]^{+},\forall v_{m}\in{\cal M}, (20)
zn​[t+1]=subscript𝑧𝑛delimited-[]𝑡1absent\displaystyle z_{n}[t+1]= [zn[t]+∑vm∈ℳαm,n[t]ℐ𝒩act,mtru[t]](n)\displaystyle\left[z_{n}[t]+\sum\nolimits_{v_{m}\in{\cal M}}\alpha_{m,n}[t]{\cal I}_{{\cal N}_{\text{act},m}^{\text{tru}}[t]]}(n)\right.
×(Rn,minc2c−Rnc2c[t])]+,∀vn∈𝒩,\displaystyle\left.\times\left(R_{n,\min}^{\text{c2c}}-R_{n}^{\text{c2c}}[t]\right)\right]^{+},\forall v_{n}\in{\cal N}, (21)

where [x]+superscriptdelimited-[]𝑥[x]^{+} is equivalent to max⁡{x,0}.𝑥0\max\{x,0\}.

For the sake of briefness, we eliminate all time coupling constraints and transform (19) to the following problem

minθ​[t],𝒂​[t]subscript𝜃delimited-[]𝑡𝒂delimited-[]𝑡\displaystyle\min_{\theta[t],{\boldsymbol{a}}[t]} {maxvi∈𝒩m,vm∈ℳV𝒢i[t]+∑vm∈ℳγm[t]\displaystyle\left\{\max_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m},v_{m}\in{\cal M}}V{\cal G}_{i}[t]+\sum\nolimits_{v_{m}\in{\cal M}}\gamma_{m}[t]\right.
(Δ−∑vi∈𝒩mαm,i​[t])+∑vn∈𝒩zn​[t]Δsubscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡subscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛𝒩subscript𝑧𝑛delimited-[]𝑡\displaystyle\left.\left(\Delta-\sum\nolimits_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}}\alpha_{m,i}[t]\right)+\sum\nolimits_{v_{n}\in{\cal N}}z_{n}[t]\right.
(∑vm∈ℳαm,n[t]ℐ𝒩act,mtru​[t](n)(Rn,minc2c−Rnc2c[t]))}\displaystyle\left.\left(\sum\nolimits_{v_{m}\in{\cal M}}\alpha_{m,n}[t]{\cal I}_{{\cal N}_{\text{act},m}^{\text{tru}}[t]}(n)\left(R_{n,{\min}}^{\text{c2c}}-R_{n}^{\text{c2c}}[t]\right)\right)\right\} (22)
s.t. (15)​ and ​(19b)−(19f).15 and 19b19f\displaystyle(\ref{add:12})\text{~{}and~{}}(\ref{add:17}\text{b})-(\ref{add:17}\text{f}). (22a)

It can be seen that objective (22) is non-convex and the constraints (19c)-(19d) imply that (22) is an integer optimization problem. Therefore, problem (22) is a mixed-integer non-convex program and there are no efficient methods to solve such kind of problems. Employing the alternating optimization techniques [29], we separately and iteratively solve 𝒂​[t]𝒂delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{a}}[t] and local model accuracy θ​[t]𝜃delimited-[]𝑡\theta[t]. In particular, we first solve for the optimal action decision 𝒂​[t]𝒂delimited-[]𝑡\boldsymbol{a}[t] given a fixed θ​[t]𝜃delimited-[]𝑡\theta[t], and then derive the optimal local model accuracy when 𝒂​[t]𝒂delimited-[]𝑡\boldsymbol{a}[t] is fixed. In time slot t𝑡t, for a given local accuracy θ​[t]𝜃delimited-[]𝑡\theta[t], due to the unique LRec-FedCS constraints (19d)-(19e), the number of possible LRec-FedCS policies is reduced from 2M​(K+1)superscript2𝑀𝐾12^{M(K+1)} to (K+1)Msuperscript𝐾1𝑀(K+1)^{M}. However, the number of participation modes is 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}. Hence, the possible action space of problem (22) is (K+1)Msuperscript𝐾1𝑀(K+1)^{M}. Solving (22) requires an exhaustive combinatorial search over all these possible action policies, where an NP-hard problem formulated by objective (22) and constraint (19b) must be solved for each of these actions. This motivates the pursuit of computationally efficient, near-optimal solutions. Before proposing a distributed method in the ensuing section, we first detail the procedure for obtaining the action space 𝑨​[t]𝑨delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{A}}[t], which is then used as a comparison method.

VI-B Centralized Method for LRef-FedCS

Upon introducing the notation of 𝒩msubscript𝒩𝑚{\cal N}_{m} for each vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} and the extend definition of αm,i​[t],vi∈𝒩msubscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚\alpha_{m,i}[t],v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}, PMDM is implicitly determined by the LRef-FedCS procedure, in the following, so that our main concern focus on the latter, i.e., 𝜶​[t].𝜶delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}[t]. To visualize the interaction between the participation mode decision and the LRef-FedCS on the feasible solution space of problem (22), a generic function is defined on set 𝒩mtru​[t]∪{m}superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚trudelimited-[]𝑡𝑚{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{tru}}[t]\cup\{m\} of vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} to assign its computation time of one local iteration relative to the selected client, which is mathematically expressed as

VI-C Local Model Accuracy Optimization

With the obtained optimal action policy 𝒂​[t]𝒂delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{a}}[t] for the announced training task t𝑡t, the optimal local model accuracy θ​[t]𝜃delimited-[]𝑡\theta[t] can be deduced as follows

It is noted that, for each vi∈𝒩m,vm∈ℳformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m},v_{m}\in{\cal M}, Am,i​(𝒂​[t])subscript𝐴𝑚𝑖𝒂delimited-[]𝑡A_{m,i}(\boldsymbol{a}[t]) and Bm,i​(𝒂​[t])subscript𝐵𝑚𝑖𝒂delimited-[]𝑡B_{m,i}(\boldsymbol{a}[t]) are the weighted sum of the time cost and energy consumption of the computation and communication phases, respectively. C​(𝒂​[t])𝐶𝒂delimited-[]𝑡C(\boldsymbol{a}[t]) accounts for the penalty due to the long-term constraints on the action decision 𝒂​[t]𝒂delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{a}}[t] in time slot t𝑡t. Intuitively, given the action decision 𝒂​[t]𝒂delimited-[]𝑡{\boldsymbol{a}}[t], Am,i​(𝒂​[t])subscript𝐴𝑚𝑖𝒂delimited-[]𝑡A_{m,i}(\boldsymbol{a}[t]), Bm,i​(𝒂​[t])subscript𝐵𝑚𝑖𝒂delimited-[]𝑡B_{m,i}(\boldsymbol{a}[t]), and C​(𝒂​[t])𝐶𝒂delimited-[]𝑡C(\boldsymbol{a}[t]) become constants.

In each time slot t𝑡t, for each combination of feasible action decisions of vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M}, the optimization problem (25) should be solved. For ease of exposition, we set

F​(θ​[t])=𝐹𝜃delimited-[]𝑡absent\displaystyle F(\theta[t])= maxvi∈𝒩m,vm∈ℳ{V1−θ​[t]log(1θ​[t])Am,i(𝒂[t])\displaystyle\max_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m},v_{m}\in{\cal M}}\left\{\frac{V}{1-\theta[t]}\log\left(\frac{1}{\theta[t]}\right)A_{m,i}(\boldsymbol{a}[t])\right.
+V1−θ​[t]Bm,i(𝒂[t])}+C(𝒂[t]).\displaystyle\left.+\frac{V}{1-\theta[t]}B_{m,i}(\boldsymbol{a}[t])\right\}+C(\boldsymbol{a}[t]). (30)

Thus, the optimal model accuracy θ​[t]𝜃delimited-[]𝑡\theta[t] in time slot t𝑡t can be obtained by deducing from the following unconstraint problem transformed from (25):

min0≤θ​[t]≤1⁡F​(θ​[t]).subscript0𝜃delimited-[]𝑡1𝐹𝜃delimited-[]𝑡\displaystyle\min_{0\leq\theta[t]\leq 1}F(\theta[t]). (31)

Following the SGHS algorithm [30], problem (31) can be solved by using the this heuristic optimization approach described in a five-tuple SGHS≡⟨HMS,HMCR,PAR,BW,NI⟩SGHSHMSHMCRPARBWNI\text{SGHS}\equiv\langle\text{HMS},\text{HMCR},\text{PAR},\text{BW},\text{NI}\rangle consisting of the following components, namely Harmony Memory Size (HMS), Harmony Memory Consideration Rate (HMCR), Pitch Adjustment Rate (PAR), Distance BandWidth (BW), and the number of Improvisations (NI). More precisely, the introduced parameters HMCR, PAR, and BW are adaptively adjusted as the iteration process. Entries in the harmony memory (HM) are extracted with probability HMCR. A large HMCR is conductive to local search, thereby improving the convergence of the SGHS algorithm, while a small HMCR increases the diversity of the HM. In the pitch adjustment process, PAR indicates that a neighboring value fine-tuned from the value selected in the HM will be extracted with probability PAR×HMCRPARHMCR\text{PAR}\times\text{HMCR}. Upon introducing parameter PAR, the exploitation of the chosen element in the HM is enhanced with a large value of PAR, whilst the diversity of the HM is increased for a relative small value of PAR. Note that the values of HMCR and PAR are difficult to determine, due to the contradiction between local exploitation and global exploration in the SGHS algorithm. In this paper, without losing generality, we let HMCR and PAR obey normal distributions based on the empirically recommended distribution [31], i.e., HMCR∼𝒩​(μHMCR,σHMCR2)similar-toHMCR𝒩subscript𝜇HMCRsuperscriptsubscript𝜎HMCR2\text{HMCR}\sim{\cal N}(\mu_{\text{HMCR}},\sigma_{\text{HMCR}}^{2}) and PAR∼𝒩​(μPAR,σPAR2)similar-toPAR𝒩subscript𝜇PARsuperscriptsubscript𝜎PAR2\text{PAR}\sim{\cal N}(\mu_{\text{PAR}},\sigma_{\text{PAR}}^{2}), respectively. Moreover, the empirically adjust principle of the BW in iteration r𝑟r can be inferred from [32]

BW​(r)={BWmax−BWmax−BWminNI​2​r,if ​r<NI2,BWmin,if ​r≥NI2,BW𝑟casessubscriptBWsubscriptBWsubscriptBWNI2𝑟if 𝑟NI2subscriptBWif 𝑟NI2\displaystyle\text{BW}(r)=\begin{cases}\text{BW}_{\max}-\frac{\text{BW}_{\max}-\text{BW}_{\min}}{\text{NI}}2r,&\text{if~{}}r<\frac{\text{NI}}{2},\\ \text{BW}_{\min},&\text{if~{}}r\geq\frac{\text{NI}}{2},\end{cases} (32)

where BWminsubscriptBW\text{BW}_{\min} and BWmaxsubscriptBW\text{BW}_{\max} denote the preset minimum and maximum search scopes of the SGHS algorithm. Let L𝐿L be the update period of HMCR and PAR according to the recording parameters. For more detailed information concerning the harmony search (HS), the reader is referred to an excellent contribution by Geem and Lee [31, 33, 32]. The implementation of the algorithm is presented in Algorithm 1.

The optimal solution to (22) can be obtained by iteratively performing Steps 1-4 and Algorithm 1. However, the above optimal solution with an exponential computational complexity is prohibitive in practice settings with a large set of workers. This motivates the pursuit of computationally efficient near-optimal solutions. Thus, in the following, we further develop a low-complexity method to obtain a suboptimal solution to problem (22) through exploiting the local information of each RC vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M}. Drawing on the matching game theory [34], we employ a matching game based distributed algorithm to solve problem (22), because of its ability to tackle mixed integer optimization problems, which will be presented in the ensuing section.

VII Distributed LRef-FedCS Method

In this section, we present the formulation of the LRef-FedCS process as a matching game, where URs minimize their individual costs in a distributed manner. We analyze the existence of a stable solution and demonstrate that the complexity of the analysis algorithm is polynomial.

VII-A Matching Game Based Distributed Method Design

In the previous section, the FL server coordinates the optimal LRef-FedCS in a centralized manner. However, we cannot design a decentralized and scalable algorithm using Steps 1-4, which use an objective function that requires global information of all clients (URs and UnRCs). Due to the distributed nature of mobile IoT devices, each RC is only aware of the UnRCs within its individual sensing area without additional signaling and overhead. In the following, we denote the set of UnRCs located in the sensing area of vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} by 𝒩mnei​[t]superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t], namely 𝒩mnei​[t]:={vn∈𝒩:dis​(vm,vn)≤smax&wm,n>0}assignsuperscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡conditional-setsubscript𝑣𝑛𝒩dissubscript𝑣𝑚subscript𝑣𝑛subscript𝑠subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛0{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t]:=\{v_{n}\in{\cal N}:\text{dis}(v_{m},v_{n})\leq s_{\max}~{}\&~{}w_{m,n}>0\}, where smaxsubscript𝑠s_{\max} is the sensing distance of RCs. Therefore, at the renewal time instance τ​[t]𝜏delimited-[]𝑡\tau[t], we define 𝑨~m​[t]={𝒂~m​[t]}subscript~𝑨𝑚delimited-[]𝑡subscript~𝒂𝑚delimited-[]𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}_{m}[t]=\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{a}}_{m}[t]\} as the action set of vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m}, where 𝒂~m​[t]={ϕm​[t],𝜶~m​[t]}subscript~𝒂𝑚delimited-[]𝑡subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚delimited-[]𝑡subscript~𝜶𝑚delimited-[]𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{a}}_{m}[t]=\{\phi_{m}[t],{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}}_{m}[t]\} is the action policy based on the local information, and 𝜶~m​[t]={αm,i​[t],i∈𝒩mnei​[t]∪{vm}}.subscript~𝜶𝑚delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝛼𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑣𝑚\tilde{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}_{m}[t]=\{\alpha_{m,i}[t],i\in{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t]\cup\{v_{m}\}\}. In problem (35), the objective is reduced to maximize the utility of each RC by LRef-FedCS in parallel. A nature framework for studying such a combinatorial problem is offered by the matching theory which can achieve a distributed solution. Following the two-sided matching game [35], we formulate the LRef-FedCS as a matching game between the RCs and UnRCs, and then present a matching algorithm that can find a stable matching which is a key concept for a matching game. As can be seen from constraints (19e) and (19f), we assume that each RC forms a set that can recommend a single UnRC. However, for the recommended UnRC, the computation time required by the UnRC should be below the tolerable predefined upper bound, i.e., constraint (15). Similarly, each UnRC also forms a set to accommodate an RC among all the RCs. Therefore, our design amounts to a one-to-one matching given in the tuple ℳ​𝒢≡⟨ℳ,𝒩,≻ℳ,≻𝒩⟩ℳ𝒢ℳ𝒩subscriptsucceedsℳsubscriptsucceeds𝒩{\cal MG}\equiv\langle{\cal M},{\cal N},\succ_{\cal M},\succ_{\cal N}\rangle, where ≻ℳ:≜{≻vm}vm∈ℳ\succ_{\cal M}:\triangleq\{\succ_{v_{m}}\}_{v_{m}\in{\cal M}} and ≻𝒩:≜{≻vn}vn∈𝒩\succ_{\cal N}:\triangleq\{\succ_{v_{n}}\}_{v_{n}\in{\cal N}} represent the sets of preference relation of the RCs and UnRCs, respectively. Formally, we define the relation “prefer” for vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} between vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} and vn′subscript𝑣superscript𝑛′v_{n^{\prime}} in the following definition.

Definition 1

Note that the set of preference relations of UnRCs over vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} is also based on the preference function Um​(𝒂~m​[t],θ​[t])subscript𝑈𝑚subscript~𝒂𝑚delimited-[]𝑡𝜃delimited-[]𝑡U_{m}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{a}}_{m}[t],\theta[t]). This is because that the long-term QoS requirements of the UnRCs are embedded into the utility function. Thus, obtaining the preference value of vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N} over vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} also relies on the utility Um​(𝒂~m​[t],θ​[t])subscript𝑈𝑚subscript~𝒂𝑚delimited-[]𝑡𝜃delimited-[]𝑡U_{m}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{a}}_{m}[t],\theta[t]), mainly due to the part of [(34)-1]. Moreover, we define the preference list of each vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} (respectively, vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N}) over vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N} (respectively, vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M}) by ℒmrcsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑚rc{\cal L}_{m}^{\text{rc}} (respectively, ℒnunrcsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑛unrc{\cal L}_{n}^{\text{unrc}}), which is ranked by the preference value in non-increasing order. However, as shown in Definition 1, the two sets of players in the matching game are the subsets of ℳℳ{\cal M} and 𝒩𝒩{\cal N}, respectively. In order to be consistent with the matching game ℳ​𝒢ℳ𝒢{\cal MG}, the preference list ℒmrcsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑚rc{\cal L}_{m}^{\text{rc}} of each vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} consists of two parts. The first part is ranked by the preference value in non-increasing order over vn,vn∈𝒩mnei​[t]subscript𝑣𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡v_{n},v_{n}\in{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t], whilst the second part is just set vn,vn∈𝒩∖𝒩mnei​[t]subscript𝑣𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡v_{n},v_{n}\in{\cal N}\setminus{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t]. The preference value corresponding to the elements in the set is set to be −∞-\infty. Similarly, the preference list ℒnunrcsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑛unrc{\cal L}_{n}^{\text{unrc}} of each vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N} comes from two subsets ℳn​[t]subscriptℳ𝑛delimited-[]𝑡{\cal M}_{n}[t] and ℳ∖ℳn​[t]ℳsubscriptℳ𝑛delimited-[]𝑡{\cal M}\setminus{\cal M}_{n}[t], where the preference value of vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N} over vm,vm∈ℳ∖ℳn​[t]subscript𝑣𝑚subscript𝑣𝑚ℳsubscriptℳ𝑛delimited-[]𝑡v_{m},v_{m}\in{\cal M}\setminus{\cal M}_{n}[t] is set to be −∞-\infty, and the preference list over ℳn​[t]subscriptℳ𝑛delimited-[]𝑡{\cal M}_{n}[t] is ranked in non-increasing order. Accordingly, a matching game based decentralized method is developed, since only local information is used for each vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} and vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N}. In addition, the matching game based decentralized method has a stable strategy that is a key concept in matching theory [36] and can be defined as follows.

Definition 2

A matching ℳ​𝒢ℳ𝒢\cal MG is stable for each time slot t𝑡t if there is no blocking pair (vm,vn)subscript𝑣𝑚subscript𝑣𝑛(v_{m},v_{n}), where vm∈ℳ,vn∈𝒩formulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑚ℳsubscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{m}\in{\cal M},v_{n}\in{\cal N}, such that vn≻vm[t]ℳ​𝒢​(vm)superscriptsubscriptsucceedssubscript𝑣𝑚delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑣𝑛ℳ𝒢subscript𝑣𝑚v_{n}\succ_{v_{m}}^{[t]}{\cal MG}(v_{m}) and vm≻vn[t]ℳ​𝒢​(vn)superscriptsubscriptsucceedssubscript𝑣𝑛delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑣𝑚ℳ𝒢subscript𝑣𝑛v_{m}\succ_{v_{n}}^{[t]}{\cal MG}(v_{n}), where ℳ​𝒢​(vm)ℳ𝒢subscript𝑣𝑚{\cal MG}(v_{m}) and ℳ​𝒢​(vn)ℳ𝒢subscript𝑣𝑛{\cal MG}(v_{n}) represent the current partners of vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} and vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n}, respectively.

Given a fixed balance parameter V𝑉V, in each time slot t𝑡t, the stable solution (ℳ​𝒢∗​[t],θ∗​[t])ℳsuperscript𝒢delimited-[]𝑡superscript𝜃delimited-[]𝑡({\cal MG}^{*}[t],\theta^{*}[t]) produced by Algorithm 2 is a local solution to the optimization problem (35).

VII-B Algorithm Summary and Discussions

In our method, a stable solution ensures that no matched RC will benefit from deviating from its client selection. The output of the matching game-based distributed method is the action policy 𝒂~m​[t]subscript~𝒂𝑚delimited-[]𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{a}}_{m}[t] of each vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M} that maximizes its utility Umsubscript𝑈𝑚U_{m}. The the pseudo code to find a stable matching ℳ​𝒢ℳ𝒢\cal MG between the RCs and UnRCs is given in Algorithm 2. Furthermore, the computational complexity of Stage I in Algorithm 2 can be shown to be 2 by 𝒪​(maxvm∈ℳ,vn∈𝒩⁡|𝒩mnei​[t]|⋅|ℳn​[t]|).𝒪subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑚ℳsubscript𝑣𝑛𝒩⋅superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡subscriptℳ𝑛delimited-[]𝑡{\cal O}(\max_{v_{m}\in{\cal M},v_{n}\in{\cal N}}|{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t]|\cdot|{\cal M}_{n}[t]|). In fact, we denote the complexity of building the preference list ℒmrc​[t]superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑚rcdelimited-[]𝑡{\cal L}_{m}^{\text{rc}}[t] for each vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} by 𝒪​(|𝒩mnei​[t]|​log⁡(|𝒩mnei​[t]|))𝒪superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡{\cal O}(|{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t]|\log(|{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t]|)). Consequently, the complexity of building the preference list ℒnrc​[t]superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑛rcdelimited-[]𝑡{\cal L}_{n}^{\text{rc}}[t] at each vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} is 𝒪​(|ℳn​[t]|​|𝒩mnei​[t]|​log⁡(|ℳn​[t]|​|𝒩mnei​[t]|))𝒪subscriptℳ𝑛delimited-[]𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡subscriptℳ𝑛delimited-[]𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡{\cal O}(|{\cal M}_{n}[t]||{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t]|\log(|{\cal M}_{n}[t]||{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t]|)). VIII Simulation Results and Discussions

VIII-A Simulation Environments and Settings

In this section, the short- and long-term performances of the proposed centralized (Steps 1-4) and distributed methods are evaluated and compared. To keep the complexity of the simulations tractable while considering a significantly loaded system, we focus on a circular community with an area π​(50×50)​ m2𝜋5050superscript m2\pi(50\times 50)\text{~{}m}^{2} centered around its server, where M𝑀M RCs are randomly distributed, each with a sensing radius of smax=18​ msubscript𝑠18 ms_{\max}=18\text{~{}m}. To model a relatively real-world mobility environment, the Gauss-Markov Mobility Mode [37] originally constructed to simulate personal communications systems [38] is employed in our simulations. In addition, the social relationship 𝑾𝑾{\boldsymbol{W}} can be established through online social networks, whose entries wm,nsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑛w_{m,n} are quantified by the average communication frequency between the RC vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} and UnRC vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} [26].

Based on the communication phase described in Section V.A, it is necessary to carefully configure the simulation parameters. First, we consider a wireless FL with carrier frequency 2.3​ GHz2.3 GHz2.3\text{~{}GHz} and bandwidth 0.2​ MHz.0.2 MHz0.2\text{~{}MHz}. We set the path loss exponents for each individual link and the path loss at the reference distance 1​ m1 m1\text{~{}m} to be 333 and 303030 dBm, respectively, and adopt Rayleigh fading to reproduce multipath effects [27]. We assume that perfect channel information is known at the receivers pilot signals [27]. Throughout the simulations, unless otherwise specified, we adopt the parameters reported in Table II, where, for simplicity, each UnRC is assumed to have the same long-term QoS requirement, i.e., Rminc2csuperscriptsubscript𝑅c2cR_{\min}^{\text{c2c}}, and each potential participant is also assumed to have the same computation time constraint in one local iteration, i.e., TmaxcmpsuperscriptsubscriptTcmp\text{T}_{\max}^{\text{cmp}}. Moreover, all the RCs are assumed to have the same CPU frequency fm=frcsubscript𝑓𝑚subscript𝑓rcf_{m}=f_{\text{rc}} and transmit power budget pmmax=prcmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑝rcp_{m}^{\max}=p_{\text{rc}}^{\max}. Likewise, the same CPU frequency fn=furcsubscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑓urcf_{n}=f_{\text{urc}} and the maximum transmit power pnmax=purcmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑝urcp_{n}^{\max}=p_{\text{urc}}^{\max} are imposed for all UnRCs. In addition, we set λt=1/6superscript𝜆𝑡16\lambda^{t}={1}/{6} and λe=5/6superscript𝜆𝑒56\lambda^{e}={5}/{6}.

VIII-B Algorithm Discussion

1) Validation of convergence of SGHS: Fig. 4 depicts the convergence of SGHS (Alg. 1) in one training task. We draw the maximum and minimum values of the HM to characterize the value range and convergence of the HM through solving the unconstrained problem (31) with V=0.01𝑉0.01V=0.01 and randomly selected feasible action policy 𝒂𝒂{\boldsymbol{a}}, varying the number of improvisations from 00 to 300300300. As can be seen from the figure, the gap between the two lines decreases when the number of improvisations increases. More precisely, for the NI values to the left of point ①, i.e., NI∈[0,20]NI020\text{NI}\in[0,20], the gap between the two curves in increasing iterations is significantly narrowed. However, for the NI values to the right of point ③, it is difficult to distinguish the two curves, and they converge to θ∗=1.69236×10−5superscript𝜃1.69236superscript105\theta^{*}=1.69236\times 10^{-5} quickly. It can be shown that for the iterations between points ①circled-1① and ③circled-3③, the infection points and gaps between the two curves like point ②circled-2② appear, which means that the HM is updating and adding the new θ𝜃\theta frequently. The effect of the balance parameter V𝑉V in the Lyapunov-based algorithm on the optimal solution to the SGHS process in one global round is shown in Fig. 4. As can be observed from the figure, for any given feasible action policy 𝒂𝒂{\boldsymbol{a}}, the optimal value of the local model accuracy increases with V𝑉V. This is attributed to the terms of V​Ai(m)​(𝒂)𝑉superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑚𝒂VA_{i}^{(m)}(\boldsymbol{a}) and V​Bi(m)​(𝒂)𝑉superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑚𝒂VB_{i}^{(m)}(\boldsymbol{a}) in (30), which can be regarded as coefficients for [log⁡(1/θ)/(1−θ)]delimited-[]1𝜃1𝜃[\log(1/\theta)/(1-\theta)] and [1/(1−θ)]delimited-[]11𝜃[1/(1-\theta)], respectively. Specifically, when a much larger value of V𝑉V is provided, solving (31) results in a larger optimal θ𝜃\theta, as the associated coefficients of F​(θ)𝐹𝜃F(\theta) exhibit relatively higher magnitudes.

2) Tightness of the matching game-based distributed method: To assess the gap between the solution yielded by the distributed method and the optimal solution obtained by the centralized method (Steps 1-4), Fig. 6 plots the system cost as a function of the iteration for the matching process in Algorithm 2. For any given value of V𝑉V, we first solve (22) using the centralized method and then solve the optimization problem using the distributed method under the same mentioned system settings. As can be seen from Fig. 6, the matching game-based distributed method can produce solutions close to the global optimal one, but the gap depends on the value of V𝑉V. We can observe from the results in Fig. 6 that the distributed method can perform closely to the global optimal solution with only 2.33%percent2.332.33\% bias within 101010 iterations for V=0.01𝑉0.01V=0.01. This indicates that if the value of V𝑉V is set appropriately, the proposed distributed method can yield solutions close to the optimal one rapidly.

3) Lyapunov-based algorithm characteristics: We identify the characteristics of the Lyapunov-based algorithm with respect to the renewal times (FL announced training tasks) under different values of the balance parameter V𝑉V. To this end, the time-average cost performance of the centralized and distributed methods assisted Lyapunov algorithms are evaluated and compared by varying t−1𝑡1t-1 from 00 to 300300300. Fig. 6 shows the impact of the balance parameter V𝑉V on the time-average cost for both the distributed and centralized methods assisted Lyapunov algorithms. As expected, for both the centralized and distributed methods, the time-average cost is asymptotically stable as it evolves over time. In addition to our observations in Fig. 6 with respect to t𝑡t, the performance bias between the centralized and distributed methods increases with V𝑉V. This phenomenon is implied in (30).

4) Impact of trust value distribution: To emphasize the impact of the trust distribution on the LRec-FedCS process, we define a new parameter, quantifying the clients heterogeneity regarding to trust value, as follows

Ltrust:≜minvm∈ℳ⁡maxvi∈𝒩m⁡wm,imaxvm∈ℳ⁡minvi∈𝒩m⁡wm,i.\displaystyle L_{\text{trust}}:\triangleq\frac{\min\limits_{v_{m}\in{\cal M}}\max\limits_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}}w_{m,i}}{\max\limits_{v_{m}\in{\cal M}}\min\limits_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}}w_{m,i}}. (36)

We see that higher values of Ltrustsubscript𝐿trustL_{\text{trust}} indicate higher levels of client heterogeneity. For example, Ltrust=1subscript𝐿trust1L_{\text{trust}}=1 can be considered as a low heterogeneity level due to balanced trust distribution, which means that the lower limit of the maximum sequence (numerator) is the same as the upper limit of the minimum sequence (denominator). In our simulations, to vary Ltrustsubscript𝐿trustL_{\text{trust}}, the trust level wm,ksubscript𝑤𝑚𝑘w_{m,k} between the RCs (belong to set ℳℳ{\cal M}) and UnRCs (located in set 𝒩𝒩{\cal N}) is generated with the fraction minvm∈ℳ,vn∈𝒩⁡wm,nmaxvm∈ℳ,vn∈𝒩⁡wm,n∈{1,0.9,0.8,…,0.1}subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑚ℳsubscript𝑣𝑛𝒩subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑚ℳsubscript𝑣𝑛𝒩subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛10.90.8…0.1\frac{\min_{v_{m}\in{\cal M},v_{n}\in{\cal N}}w_{m,n}}{\max_{v_{m}\in{\cal M},v_{n}\in{\cal N}}w_{m,n}}\in\{1,0.9,0.8,\ldots,0.1\}, but the maximal value of the trust level maxvm∈𝒩,vn∈𝒩⁡wm,nsubscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑚𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛\max_{v_{m}\in{\cal N},v_{n}\in{\cal N}}w_{m,n} is kept at the same value one. Figs. 7(a) and (b) show the influence of Ltrustsubscript𝐿trustL_{\text{trust}} on the training time cost and the average energy consumption for both centralized and distributed methods. As can be seen from the figures, the time-average training time cost and energy consumption of the proposed methods decrease for a given value of V𝑉V, as Ltrustsubscript𝐿trustL_{\text{trust}} increases. This can be explained as follows. According to the detailed expressions presented in Section V.A, both the time and energy consumption are functions of trust level, considering a given value of prcmax,purcmax,Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑝rcsuperscriptsubscript𝑝urc𝐵p_{\text{rc}}^{\max},p_{\text{urc}}^{\max},B, as well as for a given value of frcsubscript𝑓rcf_{\text{rc}} and furcsubscript𝑓urcf_{\text{urc}}. In addition, as the parameter Ltrustsubscript𝐿trustL_{\text{trust}} increases, it leads to a more refined segmentation of communication and computing resources. This finer segmentation enhances the potential for achieving system cost efficiency.

VIII-C Performance Comparison

To gain insights into the distributed and centralized methods assisted Lyapunov-based algorithms, we compare the time-average cost performance of the proposed algorithms with those of the following methods:

  • •

    Greedy+SGHS method: select clients according to the highest trust levels and obtain local model accuracy via SGHS.

  • •

    Random+SGHS method: randomly select clients and obtain local model accuracy via SGHS.

  • •

    SQoS+SGHS method: select clients from a subset of UnRCs that currently have their own QoS requirements (i.e., clients located in 𝒩act,mtru​[t]superscriptsubscript𝒩act𝑚trudelimited-[]𝑡{\cal N}_{\text{act},m}^{\text{tru}}[t]) and obtain local model accuracy via SGHS.

  • •

    Greedy+Random method: select clients according to the highest trust levels and randomly select the local model accuracy.

  • •

    Random+Random method: randomly select clients and the local model accuracy.

  • •

    SQoS+Random method: select clients from a subset of SWs that currently have their own QoS requirements and randomly select the local model accuracy.

The performance comparison is based on the assumption that the aforementioned methods use the same feasible action set that is determined by Step 1 at each renewal time point τ​[t]𝜏delimited-[]𝑡\tau[t].

Fig. 9 compares the time-average cost achieved by all the above methods with V=1𝑉1V=1 and NI=300.NI300\text{NI}=300. As can be observed from the figure, the proposed distributed method significantly outperforms the methods in time-average cost other than the centralized method. This is not only due to the difference between the local and global information, but also because of the sequential nature of the decision-making process, where the optimal solution produced by the centralized method is to solve minθ​[t]⁡min𝒂​[t]⁡maxvi∈𝒩m​[t],vm∈ℳ⁡𝒢m,i​(𝒂​[t],θ​[t])⏞♣subscript𝜃delimited-[]𝑡superscript⏞subscript𝒂delimited-[]𝑡subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒩𝑚delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑣𝑚ℳsubscript𝒢𝑚𝑖𝒂delimited-[]𝑡𝜃delimited-[]𝑡♣\min\limits_{\theta[t]}\overbrace{\min_{\boldsymbol{a}[t]}\max_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}[t],v_{m}\in{\cal M}}{\cal G}_{m,i}({\boldsymbol{a}}[t],\theta[t])}^{\clubsuit}, and the distributed method is to solve minθ​[t]⁡maxvi∈𝒩mnei​[t],vm∈ℳ⁡min𝒂~​[t]⁡𝒢m,i​(𝒂~​[t],θ​[t])⏞♠subscript𝜃delimited-[]𝑡superscript⏞subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑚neidelimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑣𝑚ℳsubscript~𝒂delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝒢𝑚𝑖~𝒂delimited-[]𝑡𝜃delimited-[]𝑡♠\min\limits_{\theta[t]}\overbrace{\max_{v_{i}\in{\cal N}_{m}^{\text{nei}}[t],v_{m}\in{\cal M}}\min_{\tilde{\boldsymbol{a}}[t]}{\cal G}_{m,i}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{a}}[t],\theta[t])}^{\spadesuit}. Thus, the corresponding coefficients Am,isubscript𝐴𝑚𝑖A_{m,i} and Bm,isubscript𝐵𝑚𝑖B_{m,i} in the output F​(θ)𝐹𝜃F(\theta) of ♠♠\spadesuit are less than the coefficients associated with ♣♣\clubsuit. For the outcomes of ♣♣\clubsuit and ♠♠\spadesuit with a given value of V𝑉V, the corresponding V​Am,i,V​Bm,i𝑉subscript𝐴𝑚𝑖𝑉subscript𝐵𝑚𝑖VA_{m,i},VB_{m,i}, C𝐶C, and Cmsubscript𝐶𝑚C_{m} are constants. The larger the constants, the greater the incurred cost of (31). In addition, there is a long-span of average cost between the Greedy, Random, SQoS methods in conjunction with SGHS and the proposed distributed method. This is to be expected because the distributed methods yield the smallest coefficient for the same value of V𝑉V. Moreover, when the local model accuracy is randomly chosen, it leads to a substantial increase in the incurred cost, which is further exacerbated by inappropriate settings of θ𝜃\theta, as depicted Random+Random in Fig. 9.

Here, to demonstrate the superiority of the LRef-FedCS framework, we further compare the reliability performance of FL and quantify it by the time average of the successfully recommended clients’ trust values. It is clear from Figs. 9 and 9 that the highest FL reliability is produced by the Greedy method at the expense of the more system cost. It is noted that, the FL reliability of the SQoS method is relatively small, which is essentially due to the fact that this method priorities the QoS of UnRCs rather than the system cost. According to the designed trust-aided diverse resource trading principles Ξ​(⋅)Ξ⋅\Xi(\cdot) and Π​(⋅)Π⋅\Pi(\cdot) respectively described in (4) and (6), the proposed centralized and distributed methods balance well between FL reliability and system cost. According to the bandwidth segmentation of the RCs and the computational-communication resource allocation obeying the designed principles Ξ​(⋅)Ξ⋅\Xi(\cdot) and Π​(⋅)Π⋅\Pi(\cdot), respectively, both the proposed centralized and distributed LRef-FedCS strike an elegant between cost-efficiency and FL reliability.

VIII-D Performance Demonstration of Proposed Methods

1) Performance comparison versus purcmaxsuperscriptsubscriptpurcp_{\text{urc}}^{\max}: Fig. 10(a) and (b) plot the performances of the centralized and distributed methods, respectively, with V=1𝑉1V=1 and V=0.01𝑉0.01V=0.01, and purcmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑝urcp_{\text{urc}}^{\max} varied from 0​ dBm0 dBm0\text{~{}dBm} to 40​ dBm40 dBm40\text{~{}dBm}. Once again, we can observe that the centralized method outperforms the distributed method forV∈{0.01,1}𝑉0.011V\in\{0.01,1\}. As can be seen from the figures, for both the centralized and distributed methods, the average training time (energy consumption) decreases (increases) for a given value of V𝑉V, as the power budget purcmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑝urcp_{\text{urc}}^{\max} goes up. This observation can be explained with the aid of (2), (3), and (5) as follows. For a given data size, it can be shown from (3), (5) and (7) that the incurred uploading time monotonically decreases with the increasing maximum transmit power of UnRCs. By contrast, the trend with respect to energy consumption depicted in Fig. 10(b) is attributed to the exponential increase in transmit power, which dominates the ratio of the power consumption to the achieved data rate and the energy consumption increases more rapidly when purcmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑝urcp_{\text{urc}}^{\max} is larger than 30​ dBm30 dBm30\text{~{}dBm}. As can be seen from Fig. 10, it is difficult to distinguish the curves for V=1𝑉1V=1 and 0.010.010.01, when the maximum transmit power is lower than 30​ dBm30 dBm30\text{~{}dBm}.

2) Performance comparison versus QQQ: Fig. 11 presents the performance of the proposed methods with prcmax=0.5​ Wsuperscriptsubscript𝑝rc0.5 Wp_{\text{rc}}^{\max}=0.5\text{~{}W} and purcmax=0.3​ Wsuperscriptsubscript𝑝urc0.3 Wp_{\text{urc}}^{\max}=0.3\text{~{}W}, with V=1,0.1,𝑉10.1V=1,0.1, and 0.010.010.01 and Q𝑄Q varied from 104superscript10410^{4} to 3×1043superscript1043\times 10^{4}. As can be observed from the figure, both the training time in Fig. 11(a) and the average energy consumption in Fig. 11(b) increase as the data size of the clients goes up, since the data size is always detrimental to the unilateral system efficiency. According to (9) and (10), the training time and energy consumption are almost linearly with regards to the data size. Furthermore, it is noted that for the proposed two methods both the training time and energy consumption performance decrease with the increase of the value of V𝑉V.

VIII-E Implementation on the MNIST/CIFAR-10 Datasets

Note that our proposed LRef-FedCS approach for FL in the HieIoT network can be regarded as a pre-selection component integrated with existing federated platforms. In Figd. 13 and 13, to show the efficiency of our proposed LRec-FedCS approach, we run a real-world PyTorch model based on two standard datasets MNIST and CIFAR-10. We train a convolutional neural network (CNN) model with two convolutional layers, a dropout layer, and two linear fully-connected layers on the MNIST dataset, which includes a training set of 600006000060000 images and a testing set of 100001000010000 images. The CNN consists of a convolutional layer, a pooling layer, a convolutional layer, and three linear fully-connected layers and is trained on the CIFAR-10 dataset, which includes 500005000050000 training color images and 100001000010000 testing color images. In our experiments, to simulate different quality levels of local data, we generate different percentages of noisy labels for the clients (RCs and UnRCs) based on the trust values between the RCs and UnRCs. Specifically, each RC vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} owns 100​(1−wm,:/w)%100percent1subscript𝑤𝑚:𝑤100(1-w_{m,:}/w)\% noisy data, where wm,:=∑vn∈𝒩wm,nsubscript𝑤𝑚:subscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛𝒩subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛w_{m,:}=\sum_{v_{n}\in{\cal N}}w_{m,n} and w=∑vm∈ℳ,vn∈𝒩wm,n𝑤subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑚ℳsubscript𝑣𝑛𝒩subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛w=\sum_{v_{m}\in{\cal M},v_{n}\in{\cal N}}w_{m,n}. Likewise, each UnRC vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} owns 100​(1−w:,n/w)%100percent1subscript𝑤:𝑛𝑤100(1-w_{:,n}/w)\% noisy data with w:,n=∑vm∈ℳwm,nsubscript𝑤:𝑛subscriptsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳsubscript𝑤𝑚𝑛w_{:,n}=\sum_{v_{m}\in{\cal M}}w_{m,n}. Figs. 13 and 13 draw the global accuracy of the eight methods mentioned in Section VIII.C. It can be seen from the two figures that our designed centralized and distributed methods outperform the other competing methods other than the greedy method. However, the aggressive attitude towards global model accuracy exhibited by the greedy method can lead to catastrophic cost increase at the client level, thereby resulting in faster battery depletion and higher cost. It is clear from Figs. 13-13 and Fig. 9 that the solutions yielded by our proposed centralized and distributed LRef-FedCS methods with trust-aided resource scheduling is able to balance well between learning quality and cost.

IX Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed the LRef-FedCS approach for FL in the HieIoT network built through social relationships, which yields trustworthy and cost-effective client selection policies. The problem was formulated into an infinite-horizon renewal problem subject to time-average fairness constraints. Drawing on the Lyapunov optimization technique, we first transformed the time-coupled problem into a step-by-step SWET-based min-max optimization problem. To tackle the mixed-integer optimization problem, we proposed two two-stage iterarive approaches, by employing centralized search, matching game, and SGHS algorithm. In particular, the first algorithm employs specific centralized search for LRef-FedCS, and SGHS for LMAO. Instead, the second algorithm can realize autonomous client selection via the matching game process. Simulation results were presented to demonstrate that the proposed LRef-FedCS approach with the designed trust-aided resource scheduling is capable of striking a good balance between high learning quality and low system cost.
